results.title: Le Quattrocento
results.brief_description:
Episode 14 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The Quattrocento was a period of prosperity and steady progression in the arts toward the harmonious balance achieved in the High Renaissance. In concrete terms, the Quattrocento is regarded as beginning in 1401 with a competition to design the eastern doors for the Baptistery in Florence and ending in 1503 with the election of Cardinal Giuliano della Rovere as Pope Julius II. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le printemps des peuples = The awakening of the people
results.brief_description:
Episode 23 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The awakening of the people in 1830 and more famously in 1848 was a series of republican revolts against European monarchies, beginning in Sicily and spreading to France, Germany, Italy, and the Austrian Empire. They all ended in failure and repression and were followed by widespread disillusionment among liberals. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le grand siecle de Louis XIV = The great reign of Louis XIV
results.brief_description:
Episode 18 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
A lot of time in this episode is devoted to the transformation of a simple hunting lodge into a palace worthy of the magnificence of Louis XIV. In 1680 Versailles is finally inaugurated after more than 20 years of work which calls upon the best talents of the time: Levaux, Lebrun, Lenotre, Hardouin-Mansart etc… Apart from a foray into French classicism in architecture, this episode also treats of the French religious conflict, opposing catholics and protestants.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le Cro-Magnon
results.brief_description:
Episode 3 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Following the Ice Age, the era of Cro Magnon starts. The tool making technique has made vast progress. Cro-Magnon is an expert at using stones, bones and skins. He also has a strong artistic bent as demonstrated by the production of human-shaped statuettes and rock face paintings. Cro-Magnon takes the leap from hunter to herder, helped in his endeavour by his ability to domesticate dogs.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: La Revolution Francaise = the French Revolution
results.brief_description:
Episode 22 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
A fourty minute overview of the events spanning from the storming of La Bastille to the irresistible ascent of Bonaparte. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: La guerre de cent ans = The hundred year war
results.brief_description:
Episode 13 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The Hundred Years’ War was an intermittent struggle between England and France in the 14th-15th century. The main reasons for disputes included the question of the legitimate succession to the French crown. The struggle involved several generations of English and French claimants to the crown and actually occupied a period of more than 100 years. By convention it is said to have started in 1337 and ended in 1453, but there had been periodic fighting over the question of English fiefs in France going back to the 12th century. Historians have long considered the Hundred Years’ War a milestone in the development of national consciousness in western Europe. The English, after their many successes and frustrations, were finally cured of their taste for continental intervention, and the English monarchs turned increasingly to the problems of internal development. The hard-fought success of the house of Valois in securing the French crown helped insure that France would not become a realm in name only, partitioned among numerous independent princes. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: La Belle Epoque
results.brief_description:
Episode 24 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
What is commonly know as La Belle Epoque covers the years from 1870 to 1914. It is a time of great progress, both intellectual and technical. This episode focuses of the advances in the automotive industry and railways. Other topics include: the colinzation of the African continent, the construction of the Metro in Paris and the cinematograph. The October Revolution in Russia and the beginning of the mobilization in 1914 are also mentionned.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'homme de Neandertal
results.brief_description:
Episode 2 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).This episode takes us among a tribe of hunters and gatherers to find out more about their tool making techniques. We also discover how their society is affected by the Ice Age.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'angleterre D'elizabeth = Elizabethan England
results.brief_description:
Episode 16 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Elizabeth I becomes Queen at 25. Her 39 articles lay the foundation for the Anglican church. Declared a heretic by the Pope, she also has to battle with Spain for naval supremacy. Other topics include: the beginning of circumnavigation, the voyages of Sr Francis Drake and the settlement of North America.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'age des Vikings
results.brief_description:
Episode 10 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The Carolingian Empire has crumbled. In Southern Europe, the Sarazins have invaded Sicily, Rome and Provence. In the East, the Magyars make progress toward Lombardia, Venetia and Burgundy. The North is about to experience the full might of the Normans. This episode covers the organization of Viking society as well as their advances in boat building techniques and marine navigation instrumentation.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].
